ygData.subject: Re: Speciation and Genome Clusters in the Encoding Space
ygData.msgSnippet: I agree, Ken. One example cheap solution for good stability is ensuring that the compatibility threshold is adequate to the limits of the system. Maybe

I agree, Ken. One example cheap solution for good stability is 
ensuring th=
at the compatibility threshold is adequate to the limits of 
the system. Ma=
ybe something like analyzing the whole population each 
generation (in case=
 of generational approach) and determining the best 
compatibility threshol=
d in a more sophisticated way than simply 
raising and lowering it. 

Peter=


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> =
Peter, yes, that is another way that it could be done that I forgot 
to
> m=
ention:  You could characterize species by some kind of 
consolidated
> sta=
tistic like their mean weights on shared dimensions or something
> like tha=
t.  It may again lead to some kind of stability, or maybe it
> has another =
benefit.  It does seem more principled in terms of
> characterizing what a =
species is.  
> 
> However, I am not sure if it would have any benefit towa=
rds
> performance, which is probably the most significant issue.  Although
=
> it would make more sense in principle, it may simply not be as good 
as
>=
 forcing species to cluster around their champions.  It is an 
empirical
> =
issue and I do not know the answer to it.  
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoo=
groups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@>
> wrote:
> >
> > Hi Ken,=
 
> > 
> > > My implementation currently chooses a single representative of=
 
each
> > > species and new individuals in the population are compared wit=
h 
the
> > > list of representatives in order.  The new individual is place=
d 
in 
> > the
> > > first species with a representative that is within the=
 
compatibility
> > > distance.  
> > > 
> > > One other thing some people =
don't realize is that my 
implementation
> > > sorts the genomes in each sp=
ecies in order of their fitness, 
which
> > > means ultimately that the rep=
resentative becomes the individual 
with
> > > highest fitness.
> > > 
> > =

> > This issue is something I was thinking of very often. Because one 
> >=
 species can be defined as a group of genomes that have many 
matching 
> >=
 genes close to each other (with respect to the global 
compatibility
> thr=
eshold), it is possible that the representative of a species 
could 
> > be=
 kind of generalized data across all members of the species, not 
> > just =
one genome. 
> > 
> > For example, the representative can be recomputed eve=
ry 
generation, in 
> > a process where all members mate into one single in=
dividual which 
> > becomes the representative of the species. All genes sh=
ould be 
allowed 
> > to be inherited in an iterative process resulting in =
a genome that 
> > carries all complexity of all individuals of the species=
. Can this 
be 
> > considered a good representative? Or maybe just regular=
 mating, 
where 
> > excess/disjoint genes are inherited from more fit memb=
ers. I don't 
> > know what effect this could have. And it is important tha=
t the 
weights 
> > of matching genes should be averaged during mating.
> >=
 
> > The idea is that the representative of a species can be not just a 
>=
 > genome that is existing as a member, but a special genome that is 
only =

> > used during clustering, as the "overall picture" of genetic 
distance.=
 
> > 
> > Does it make sense? 
> > 
> > Peter
> >
>
